standard_metadata.standard_description: Multiply a whole number of up to four digits by a one-digit whole number, and multiply two two-digit numbers, using strategies based on place value and the properties of operations. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.

question.content: **Use partial products to multiply $73\times 4$.**  ||| -:|-: | :- |$73$ || |$\underline{{}\times 4}$ || Step 1|  | $4 \times $ | Step 2 |$\underline{{}+280}$ | $4 \times 70$| Step 3 | ||

hints.content: Let's break up the top factor by place value.  Then we can multiply each part by $4$ to get parts of the product.  Finally, let's add up all of partial products to get the total product.
$\begin{align} 7\blueE{3}&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonE{4}}&\\ \tealE{12}&\quad \maroonE{4} \times \blueE{3} \\ \end{align}$
$\begin{align} \blueE{7}3&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonE{4}}&\\ 12&\quad {4} \times {3} \\ \underline{{}+\tealE{280}}&\quad \maroonE{4} \times \blueE{70} \\ \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 73&\\ \underline{{} \times 4}&\\ \purpleD{12}&\quad {4} \times {3} \\ \underline{{}+\purpleD{280}}&\quad {4} \times {70} \\ 292 \end{align}$
Here is the completed equation using partial products:  $\begin{align} 73&\\ \underline{{} \times 4}&\\ {12}&\quad {4} \times {3} \\ \underline{{}+{280}}&\quad {4} \times {70} \\ 292 \end{align}$

question.content: **Use partial products to multiply $52\times 6$.**  || -:|-: | :- |$52$ | |$\underline{{}\times 6}$ | Step 1| | $6 \times {}$  Step 2| $\underline{{}+12}$ | $6 \times 2$ Step 3|  |

hints.content: Let's break up the top factor by place value.  Then we can multiply each part by $6$ to get parts of the product.  Finally, let's add up all of partial products to get the total product.
$\begin{align} \blueE{5}2&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonE{6}}&\\ \goldE{300}&\quad \maroonE{6} \times \blueE{50} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 5\blueE{2}&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonE{6}}&\\ 300&\quad 6\times {50}\\ \underline{{}+\goldE{12}}&\quad \maroonE{6} \times \blueE{2} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 52&\\ \underline{{} \times 6}&\\ \purpleD{300}&\quad{6} \times{50} \\ \underline{{}+\purpleD{12}}&\quad 6\times {2}\\ 312 \end{align}$
Here is the completed equation using partial products:  $\begin{align} 52&\\ \underline{{} \times 6}&\\ 300&\quad{6} \times{50} \\ \underline{{}+12}&\quad 6\times {2}\\ 312 \end{align}$

question.content: **Use partial products to multiply $826\times 3$.**  || -:|-: | :- |$826$ | |$\underline{{}\times~~ 3}$ | Step 1|$2{,}400$| $3 \times 800$ Step 2| |  $3 \times {}$  Step 3|$\underline{{}+18}$| $3 \times 6$ Step 4| |

hints.content: Let's break up the top factor by place value.  Then we can multiply each part by $3$ to get parts of the product.  Finally, let's add up all of partial products to get the total product.
$\begin{align} \blueE{8}26&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonE{3}}&\\ \goldE{2{,}400}&\quad \maroonE{3} \times \blueE{800} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 8\blueE{2}6&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonE{3}}&\\ 2{,}400&\quad 3 \times 800 \\ \goldE{60}&\quad \maroonE{3} \times \blueE{20} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 82\blueE{6}&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonE{3}}&\\ 2{,}400&\quad 3 \times 800\\ 60&\quad 3 \times 20\\ \underline{{}+\goldE{18}}&\quad \maroonE{3} \times \blueE{6} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 826&\\ \underline{{} \times 3}&\\ \purpleD{2{,}400}&\quad 3 \times 800\\ \purpleD{60}&\quad {3} \times {20} \\ \underline{{}+\purpleD{18}}&\quad {3} \times 6\\ 2{,}478 \end{align}$

Here is the completed equation using partial products:  $\begin{align} 826&\\ \underline{{} \times 3}&\\ {2{,}400}&\quad 3 \times 800\\ {60}&\quad {3} \times {20} \\ \underline{{}+{18}}&\quad {3} \times 6\\ 2{,}478 \end{align}$

question.content: **Use partial products to multiply $391\times7$.**  || -:|-: | :- |$391$ | |$\underline{{}\times~~ 7}$ |  Step 1|$7$ |$7 \times 1$ Step 2||  $7 \times {}$  Step 3|$\underline{{}+2{,}100}$| $7 \times 300$ Step 4| |

hints.content: Let's break up the top factor by place value.  Then we can multiply each part by $7$ to get parts of the product.  Finally, let's add up all of partial products to get the total product.
$\begin{align} 39\blueE{1}&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonE{7}}&\\ \goldE{7}&\quad \maroonE{7} \times \blueE{1} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 3\blueE{9}1&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonE{7}}&\\ 7&\quad {7} \times 1{} \\ \goldE{630}&\quad \maroonE{7} \times \blueE{90} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} \blueE{3}91&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonE{7}}&\\ 7&\quad {7} \times 1 \\ {630}&\quad {7} \times {90} \\ \underline{{}+\goldE{2{,}100}}&\quad \maroonE{7} \times \blueE{300} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 391&\\ \underline{{} \times 7}&\\ \purpleD{7}&\quad {7} \times 1 \\ \purpleD{630}&\quad {7} \times {90}\\ \underline{{}+\purpleD{2{,}100}}&\quad {7} \times {300}\\ 2{,}737 \end{align}$

Here is the completed equation using partial products:  $\begin{align} 391&\\ \underline{{} \times 7}&\\ {7}&\quad {7} \times 1 \\ {630}&\quad {7} \times {90}\\ \underline{{}+{2{,}100}}&\quad {7} \times {300}\\ 2{,}737 \end{align}$

question.content: **Use partial products to multiply $2{,}104\times8$.**  || -:|-: | :- |$2{,}104$ | |$\underline{{}\times~~~~ 8}$ |  Step 1|$32$ |$8 \times 4$ Step 2|$0$ | $8\times0$ Step 3||  $8 \times {}$  Step 4|$\underline{{}+16{,}000}$| $8 \times 2{,}000$ Step 5| |

hints.content: Let's break up the top factor by place value.  Then we can multiply each part by $8$ to get parts of the product.  Finally, let's add up all of partial products to get the total product.
$\begin{align} 2{,}10\blueE{4}&\\ \underline{{} \times~~~ \maroonE{8}}&\\ \goldE{32}&\quad \maroonE{8} \times \blueE{4} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 2{,}1\blueE{0}4&\\ \underline{{} \times~~~ \maroonE{8}}&\\ 32&\quad {8} \times {4}\\ \goldE{0}&\quad \maroonE{8} \times \blueE{0} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 2{,}\blueE{1}04&\\ \underline{{} \times~~~ \maroonE{8}}&\\ 32&\quad {8} \times {4}\\ 0&\quad{8} \times{0}\\ \goldE{800}&\quad \maroonE{8} \times \blueE{100} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} \blueE{2}{,}104&\\ \underline{{} \times~~~ \maroonE{8}}&\\ 32&\quad {8} \times {4}\\ 0&\quad{8} \times{0}\\ 800&\quad {8} \times {100}\\ \underline{{}+\goldE{16{,}000}}&\quad \maroonE{8} \times \blueE{2{,}000} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 2{,}104&\\ \underline{{} \times~~~ 8}&\\ \purpleD{32}&\quad {8} \times {4}\\ \purpleD{0}&\quad{8} \times{0}\\ \purpleD{800}&\quad {8} \times {100}\\ \underline{{}+\purpleD{16{,}000}}&\quad {8} \times {2{,}000}\\ 16{,}832 \end{align}$

Here is the completed equation using partial products:  $\begin{align} 2{,}104&\\ \underline{{} \times~~~ 8}&\\ {32}&\quad {8} \times {4}\\ {0}&\quad{8} \times{0}\\ {800}&\quad {8} \times {100}\\ \underline{{}+{16{,}000}}&\quad {8} \times {2{,}000}\\ 16{,}832 \end{align}$

question.content: **Use partial products to multiply $4{,}955\times2$.**  || -:|-: | :- |$4{,}955$ | |$\underline{{}\times ~~~~2}$ |  Step 1|$8{,}000$| $2 \times4{,}000$ Step 2|$1{,}800$| $2\times 900$ Step 3| | $2\times{}$  Step 4|$\underline{{}+10}$ |$2 \times 5$ Step 5| |

hints.content: Let's break up the top factor by place value.  Then we can multiply each part by $2$ to get parts of the product.  Finally, let's add up all of partial products to get the total product.
$\begin{align} \blueE{4}{,}955&\\ \underline{{} \times~~~ \maroonE{2}}&\\ \goldE{8{,}000}&\quad \maroonE{2} \times \blueE{4{,}000} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 4{,}\blueE{9}55&\\ \underline{{} \times~~~ \maroonE{2}}&\\ 8{,}000&\quad 2 \times 4{,}000\\ \goldE{1{,}800}&\quad \maroonE{2} \times \blueE{900} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 4{,}9\blueE{5}5&\\ \underline{{} \times~~~ \maroonE{2}}&\\ 8{,}000&\quad 2 \times 4{,}000\\ 1{,}800&\quad {2} \times {900}\\ \goldE{100}&\quad \maroonE{2} \times \blueE{50} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 4{,}95\blueE{5}&\\ \underline{{} \times~~~ \maroonE{2}}&\\ 8{,}000&\quad 2 \times 4{,}000\\ 1{,}800&\quad {2} \times {900}\\ 100&\quad{2} \times{50}\\ \underline{{}+\goldE{10}}&\quad \maroonE{2} \times \blueE{5} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 4{,}955&\\ \underline{{} \times~~~ 2}&\\ \purpleD{8{,}000}&\quad {2} \times {4{,}000}\\ \purpleD{1{,}800}&\quad {2} \times {900}\\ \purpleD{100}&\quad{2} \times{50}\\ \underline{{}+\purpleD{10}}&\quad {2} \times {5}\\ 9{,}910 \end{align}$

Here is the completed equation using partial products:  $\begin{align} 4{,}955&\\ \underline{{} \times~~~ 2}&\\ {8{,}000}&\quad {2} \times {4{,}000}\\ {1{,}800}&\quad {2} \times {900}\\ {100}&\quad{2} \times{50}\\ \underline{{}+{10}}&\quad {2} \times {5}\\ 9{,}910 \end{align}$

question.content: Erin tried to evaluate $48\times2$ using partial products, but she made a mistake.  Her work is below.  $ \begin{align} &&48 \\ &&\underline{\times\phantom{22}2} \\ &\blueE{\text{Step 1}}\quad&\blueE{8}&& \qquad\blueE{2\times 40}\\ &\purpleE{\text{Step 2}}&\underline\purpleE{{}+\phantom{2} 16}& &\qquad\purpleE{2\times 8}\\ &\maroonE{\text{Step 3}}&\maroonE{24}& &  \end{align}$  **Find Erin's mistake.**

hints.content: Partial products help us multiply larger numbers.  We can break the first factor apart by place value and multiply the parts *in any order* by the second factor. Then we add those products to get the final product.  [[☃ explanation 1]]  Let's take a look at how Erin broke apart the numbers to multiply.

###Step $1$  $\begin{align} \blueE{4}8&\\ \underline{{} \times \blueE{2}}&\\ \blueE{80}&\quad \blueE{2} \times \blueE{40} \end{align}$  Erin said that $\blueE{2}\times\blueE{40}$ equals $\blueE{8}$. So Erin made a mistake in step $1$.
Erin made a mistake in step 1.

question.content: Molly tried to evaluate $93\times5$ using partial products, but she made a mistake.  Her work is below.  $ \begin{align} &&93 \\ &&\underline{\times\phantom{22}5} \\ &\blueE{\text{Step 1}}\quad&\blueE{150}&& \qquad\blueE{5\times30}\\ &\purpleE{\text{Step 2}}&\underline\purpleE{{}+\phantom{2} 450}& &\quad\purpleE{5\times 90}\\ &\maroonE{\text{Step 3}}&\maroonE{600}& &  \end{align}$  **Find Molly's mistake.**

hints.content: Partial products help us multiply larger numbers.  We can break the first factor apart by place value and multiply the parts *in any order* by the second factor. Then we add those products to get the final product.  [[☃ explanation 1]]  Let's take a look at how Molly broke apart the numbers to multiply.

###Step $1$  $\begin{align} 9\blueE{3}&\\ \underline{{} \times \blueE{5}}&\\ \blueE{150}&\quad \blueE{5} \times \blueE{30} \end{align}$  Molly said that there were $3$ tens, not $3$ ones, in $9\blueE{3}$. So Molly made a mistake in step $1$.
Molly made a mistake in step 1.

question.content: Kylar tried to evaluate $508\times4$ using partial products, but he made a mistake.  His work is below.  $\begin{align} &&508 \\ &&\underline{\times\phantom{22}4} \\ &\maroonE{\text{Step 1}}&\maroonE{\phantom{2}{2{,}000}}&\qquad\maroonE{4\times 500}\\ &\purpleE{\text{Step 2}}&\purpleE{{}\phantom{2} 40} &\qquad\purpleE{4\times 0}\\ &\blueE{\text{Step 3}}\quad&\underline{\blueE{{}+32}}&\qquad\blueE{4\times8}\\ &\goldE{\text{Step 4}}&\goldE{2{,}072}& &  \end{align}$  **Find Kylar's mistake.**

hints.content: Partial products help us multiply larger numbers.  We can break the first factor apart by place value and multiply the parts *in any order* by the second factor. Then we add those products to get the final product.  [[☃ explanation 1]]  Let's take a look at how Kylar broke apart the numbers to multiply.

###Step $1$  $\begin{align} \maroonE{5}08&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonE{4}}&\\ \maroonE{\phantom{2}{2{,}000}}&\qquad\maroonE{4\times 500}\\ \end{align}$  There are $5$ hundreds in $508$, and $\maroonE{4}\times\maroonE{500}=\maroonE{2{,}000}$. So Kylar did not make a mistake in step $1$.

###Step $2$  $\begin{align} 5\purpleE{0}8&\\ \underline{{} \times \purpleE{4}}&\\ 2{,}000&\quad {4} \times {500} \\ \purpleE{0}&\quad \purpleE{4} \times \purpleE{0\text{ tens}} \end{align}$  Kylar said that $\purpleE4\times\purpleE{0}$ equals $\purpleE{40}$. So Kylar made a mistake in step $2$.
Kylar made a mistake in step $2$.

question.content: Joe tried to evaluate $612\times8$ using partial products, but he made a mistake.  His work is below.  $ \begin{align} &&612 \\ &&\underline{\times\phantom{22}8} \\ &\blueE{\text{Step 1}}\quad&\blueE{16}&\qquad\blueE{8\times2}\\ &\purpleE{\text{Step 2}}&\purpleE{{}\phantom{2} 80} &\qquad\purpleE{8\times 10}\\ &\maroonE{\text{Step 3}}&\underline\maroonE{+\phantom{2}{480}}&\qquad\maroonE{8\times 60}\\ &\goldE{\text{Step 4}}&\goldE{576}& &  \end{align}$  **Find Joe's mistake.**

hints.content: Partial products help us multiply larger numbers.  We can break the first factor apart by place value and multiply the parts *in any order* by the second factor. Then we add those products to get the final product.  [[☃ explanation 1]]  Let's take a look at how Joe broke apart the numbers to multiply.

###Step $1$  $\begin{align} 61\blueE{2}&\\ \underline{{} \times \blueE{8}}&\\ \blueE{16}&\quad \blueE{8} \times \blueE{2} \end{align}$  There are $2$ ones in $612$, and $\blueE8\times\blueE2=\blueE{16}$. So Joe did not make a mistake in step $1$.

###Step $2$  $\begin{align} 6\purpleE{1}2&\\ \underline{{} \times \purpleE{8}}&\\ 16&\quad {8} \times {2} \\ {{}\purpleE{80}}&\quad \purpleE{8} \times \purpleE{10} \end{align}$  There is $1$ ten in $612$, and $\purpleE8\times\purpleE{10}=\purpleE{80}$. So Joe did not make a mistake in step $2$.

###Step $3$  $\begin{align} \maroonE612&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonE2}&\\ {16}&\qquad{8\times 2}\\ {80}&\qquad {8} \times 10\\ \underline{{}+\maroonE{4{,}800}}&\qquad\maroonE{8\times 600} \end{align}$  Joe said that there were $6$ tens, not $6$ hundreds, in $\maroonE{6}12$. So Joe made a mistake in step $3$.
Joe made a mistake in step $3$.

question.content: Denny tried to evaluate $3{,}479\times7$ using partial products, but he made a mistake.  His work is below.  $\begin{align} &&3{,}479 \\ &&\underline{\times\phantom{22}7} \\ &\blueE{\text{Step 1}}\quad&\blueE{63}&\qquad\blueE{7\times9}\\ &\tealE{\text{Step 2}}&\tealE{{}\phantom{2} 490} &\qquad\tealE{7\times 70}\\ &\maroonE{\text{Step 3}}&\maroonE{\phantom{2}{2{,}800}}&\qquad\maroonE{7\times 400}\\ &\goldE{\text{Step 4}}&\underline\goldE{+\phantom{2}{2{,}100}}&\qquad\goldE{7\times 3{,}000}\\ &\purpleE{\text{Step 5}}&\purpleE{5{,}453}& &  \end{align}$  **Find Denny's mistake.**

hints.content: Partial products help us multiply larger numbers.  We can break the first factor apart by place value and multiply the parts *in any order* by the second factor. Then we add those products to get the final product.  [[☃ explanation 1]]  Let's take a look at how Denny broke apart the numbers to multiply.

###Step $1$  $\begin{align} 3{,}47\blueE{9}&\\ \underline{{} \times \blueE{7}}&\\ \blueE{63}&\quad \blueE{7} \times \blueE{9} \end{align}$  There are $9$ ones in $3{,}479$, and $\blueE7\times\blueE9=\blueE{63}$. So Denny did not make a mistake in step $1$.

###Step $2$  $\begin{align} 3{,}4\tealE{7}9&\\ \underline{{} \times ~~~\tealE{7}}&\\ 63&\quad {7} \times {9} \\ {{}\tealE{490}}&\quad \tealE{7} \times \tealE{70} \end{align}$  There are $7$ tens in $3{,}479$, and $\tealE7\times\tealE{70}=\tealE{490}$. So Denny did not make a mistake in step $2$.

###Step $3$  $\begin{align} 3{,}\maroonE479&\\ \underline{{} \times~~~ \maroonE7}&\\ {63}&\qquad{7\times 9}\\ {490}&\qquad {7} \times 70\\ {{}\maroonE{2{,}800}}&\qquad\maroonE{7\times 400} \end{align}$  There are $4$ hundreds in $3{,}479$, and $\maroonE{7}\times\maroonE{400}=\maroonE{2{,}800}$. So Denny did not make a mistake in step $3$.

###Step $4$  $\begin{align} \goldE3{,}479&\\ \underline{{} \times~~~ \goldE7}&\\ {63}&\qquad{7\times 9}\\ {490}&\qquad {7} \times 70\\ {{}{2{,}800}}&\qquad{7\times 400}\\ \underline{+~\goldE{21{,}000}}&\qquad{\goldE{7\times3{,}000}} \end{align}$  Denny said that $\goldE{7}\times\goldE{3{,}000}$ equals $\goldE{2{,}100}$, so Denny made a make a mistake in step $4$.
Denny made a mistake in step $4$.

question.content: Lori tried to evaluate $8{,}092\times6$ using partial products, but she made a mistake.  Her work is below.  $\begin{align} &&8{,}092 \\ &&\underline{\times\phantom{22}6} \\ &\goldE{\text{Step 1}}&\goldE{{48{,}000}}&\qquad\goldE{6\times 8{,}000}\\ &\maroonE{\text{Step 2}}&\maroonE{{0}}&\qquad\maroonE{6\times 0}\\ &\tealE{\text{Step 3}}&\tealE{540} &\qquad\tealE{6\times 90}\\ &\blueE{\text{Step 4}}\quad&\underline{\blueE{{}+12}}&\qquad\blueE{6\times2}\\ &\purpleE{\text{Step 5}}&\purpleE{552}& &  \end{align}$  **Find Lori's mistake.**

hints.content: Partial products help us multiply larger numbers.  We can break the first factor apart by place value and multiply the parts *in any order* by the second factor. Then we add those products to get the final product.  [[☃ explanation 1]]  Let's take a look at how Lori broke apart the numbers to multiply.

###Step $1$  $\begin{align} \goldE8{,}092&\\ \underline{{} \times~~~ \goldE6}&\\ \goldE{48{,}000}&\qquad{\goldE{6\times8{,}000}} \end{align}$  There are $8$ thousands in $8{,}092$, and $\goldE{6}\times\goldE{8{,}000}=\goldE{48{,}000}$. So Lori did not make a mistake in step $1$.

###Step $2$  $\begin{align} 8{,}\maroonE092&\\ \underline{{} \times~~~ \maroonE6}&\\ {48{,}000}&\qquad{{6\times8{,}000}}\\ \maroonE{0}&\qquad\maroonE{6\times 0} \end{align}$  There are $0$ hundreds in $8{,}092$, and $\maroonE{6}\times\maroonE{0}=\maroonE{0}$. So Lori did not make a mistake in step $2$.

###Step $3$  $\begin{align} 8{,}0\tealE{9}2&\\ \underline{{} \times ~~~\tealE{6}}&\\ {48{,}000}&\qquad{{6\times8{,}000}}\\ {{}{0}}&\qquad{6\times 0}\\ {{}\tealE{540}}&\qquad \tealE{6} \times \tealE{90} \end{align}$  There are $9$ tens in $8{,}092$, and $\tealE6\times\tealE{90}=\tealE{540}$. So Lori did not make a mistake in step $3$.

###Step $4$  $\begin{align} 8{,}09\blueE{2}&\\ \underline{{} \times \blueE{6}}&\\ {48{,}000}&\qquad{{6\times8{,}000}}\\ {{}{0}}&\qquad{6\times 0}\\ {540}&\qquad {6} \times 90\\ \underline{{}+\blueE{12}}&\qquad \blueE{6} \times \blueE{2} \end{align}$  There are $2$ ones in $8{,}092$, and $\blueE6\times\blueE2=\blueE{12}$. So Lori did not make a mistake in step $4$.

###Step $5$  $\begin{align} 8{,}092&\\ \underline{{} \times~~~ 6}&\\ \purpleE{48{,}000}&\qquad{{6\times8{,}000}}\\ \purpleE{{}{0}}&\qquad{6\times 0}\\ \purpleE{540}&\qquad {6} \times 90\\ \underline{\purpleE{{}+12}}&\qquad{6\times 2}\\ \purpleE{48{,}552}  \end{align}$  Lori said that $\purpleE{48{,}000 + 0 + 540 + 12}$ equals $\purpleE{552}$, so Lori made a mistake in step $5$.
Lori made a mistake in step $5$.
